themes: Medieval Irish scholars (Duns Scotus: 191 ed) were major figures in European philosophy
Early medieval Irish (Eriugena) preserved and transmitted classical learning
Catholic exile networks centered on Louvain, Rome, and Spanish Netherlands
Protestant scholarship centered on Dublin, London, Oxford
Irish-language printing almost exclusively by Catholic exiles at Louvain
Sharp confessional divide in intellectual networks after Reformation
Medieval Irish scholars (Thomas Hibernicus, FitzRalph) widely read across Europe
Counter-Reformation hagiography (Colgan) preserving pre-Reformation Irish culture
Protestant Irish integrated into Royal Society and London publishing
Robert Boyle (264 editions) - most published Irish-born author
Sharp divide: Catholic exiles preserved Irish language; Protestants published in English/Latin through London
Hartlib Circle connected Irish (Boyle, Petty) to European scientific reform movement
Dublin Philosophical Society (1683) created institutional base for Irish science
Molyneux-Locke correspondence linked Dublin to London empiricism
Ulster Presbyterian networks fed into Scottish Enlightenment (Hutcheson)
Irish contributions to natural law, toleration, and political economy debates

medieval_irish_scholars.description: Medieval Irish scholars whose works were printed in the Renaissance (1450-1700)

early_medieval.context: Irish monasteries preserved classical learning during European dark ages

figures.name: John Scotus Eriugena
figures.significance: Greatest philosopher between Augustine and Aquinas. Translated Pseudo-Dionysius. De divisione naturae. At court of Charles the Bald.
figures.note: Editions rare - works suspected of pantheism

figures.name: Dungalus Hibernicus
figures.significance: Defended icons against Claudius of Turin. Carolingian scholar.

figures.name: Sedulius Scottus
figures.significance: Poet at Liège. De rectoribus Christianis (mirrors for princes). Works survive but rarely printed.
figures.note: Not to be confused with Caelius Sedulius (5th c.)

figures.name: Dicuil
figures.significance: De mensura orbis terrae - early medieval geography. First mention of Iceland.

figures.name: Duns Scotus
figures.significance: "Subtle Doctor". Major scholastic philosopher. Franciscan. Rival of Aquinas. Birthplace disputed (Ireland, Scotland, or England).

figures.name: Thomas Hibernicus
figures.significance: Manipulus Florum - florilegium of patristic quotations. Standard reference work for preachers.

figures.name: Richard FitzRalph
figures.significance: Archbishop of Armagh. Defensorium Curatorum - attacked mendicant privileges. Summa de quaestionibus Armenorum.

medieval_irish_scholars.key_insight: Medieval Irish scholars were deeply integrated into European intellectual life. Duns Scotus (191 editions) was one of the most printed philosophers of the Renaissance - more than Ficino (106). Irish contribution to scholasticism is underappreciated.
